prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Legal Bases Used by the Courts for the Protection of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Where there is no express agreement between the parties concerning disclosure and payment for an idea, the courts may still find that both parties intended that an agreement exist. Courts use a number of factors to determine whether a contract should be inferred: if the user normally compensates individuals for disclosing ideas and the idea is used, if the party uses an idea knowing the submitter expected compensation, and/or if it is the custom in the industry to compensate those who come up with ideas.[1]

If a party uses an idea which was submitted under conditions clearly indicating that the submitter expected compensation, the courts may find that an implied contract exists.[2] The Quebec Superior Court said in Arcon Canada Inc. v. Arcobec Aluminium Inc.[3] that [translation]:

… the implied term of loyalty that can be read into every contract of service explains why an employee has no right to avail himself of confidential information obtained in and for his employment, for the purpose of soliciting his employer's customers.

The French courts are more inclined than Canadian courts to favour freedom of contract over freedom to work or trade, and French courts are therefore more inclined than Commonwealth or Quebec courts to broaden the scope of the contract under the guise of interpreting it. Commonwealth and Quebec courts are generally more likely to resort to fiduciary obligations than to enforce an implied contract.[4] The American courts have also often resorted to fiduciary obligations rather than enforcing an implied contract. In Cohen v. Lafayette National Bank,[5] the court refused to find that there was an implied contract to compensate the plaintiff for an idea although the user knew that the submitter expected compensation. Courts in most jurisdictions refuse to apply an implied contract theory to protect ideas which are not novel, original and concrete.[6]

Although the courts have clearly held that a party has the right to contract for the ownership or use of an idea for profit, the contract theory has recently been the subject of considerable criticism.
M.A. Epstein, “The Law of Ideas: The Better Mousetrap Might Not be Yours” (1985), 11 Rutgers Computer & Tech. L.J. 1.
Liggett & Meyer v. Meyer, 101 Ind. App. 420, 194 N.E. 206 (1935).
Arcon Canada Inc. v. Arcobec Aluminium Inc. (1984), 5 C.I.P.R. 94 at p. 102, 7 C.P.R. (3d) 382 (Que. S.C.).
M. Bourgeois, “Protecting Business Confidences: A Comparative Study of Quebec and French Law” (1987-88), 3 I.P.J. 259 at p. 267.
Cohen v. Lafayette National Bank, 127 U.S.P.Q. 287 (N.Y. Sup. Ct. 1960).
Downey v. General Foods Corp., 31 N.Y.2d 56, 61, at pp. 61-2, 286 N.E.2d 257 (1972); Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd., [1969] R.P.C. 41 (Ch.).
